final_answer.precision_note: Reported to 3 s.f. because 5.00 g and 84.0% are both 3 s.f. inputs.

method: First find the mass of pure calcium carbonate in the limestone: m(CaCO3) = 5.00 g × 0.840 = 4.20 g. From the atomic data, Mr(CaCO3) = Ar(Ca)+Ar(C)+3Ar(O) = 40.1 + 12.0 + 3×16.0 = 100.1. Moles of CaCO3: n = m/Mr = 4.20/100.1 = 0.04196 mol. The equation CaCO3 + 2HCl → CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O shows a 1:1 molar ratio between CaCO3 and CO2, so n(CO2) = 0.04196 mol. Also from atomic data, Mr(CO2) = 12.0 + 2×16.0 = 44.0. Therefore m(CO2) = n×Mr = 0.04196 × 44.0 = 1.846 g, which rounds to 1.85 g (3 s.f.).
checks: If the sample were 100% CaCO3, CO2 would be (5.00/100.1)×44.0 ≈ 2.20 g; 84% purity gives ≈ 0.84×2.20 ≈ 1.85 g.
CO2 mass must be less than CaCO3 mass (CO2 is only part of the formula), and 1.85 g < 4.20 g.
